DOC.HEAD: Soviet Mine Strike Leader Barred From Travel to U.S.
Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Airport border guards abruptly revoked the passport and exit visa of a Soviet strike leader Friday as he was to board a flight to the United States to meet American union leaders. The U.S. Embassy filed a strong protest. Embassy spokesman Jim Bullock said the United States considered the action a violation of what U.S. officials have been told would be the new free-exit policy. Soviet officials previously had authorized the U.S. government-sponsored trip by 10 leaders of last summer's national coal strike. Soviet citizens must obtain an exit visa for each trip out of the country. But permission was refused at the last minute for Sergei V. Masalovich, a strike leader from Vorkuta in the Soviet Arctic, Bullock said. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Sergei Komolov said Masalovich's visa was canceled because the trade union committee in Vorkuta had stripped him of his duties on the strike committee. ``So he cannot be part of the official delegation,'' but may re-apply for a visa for a private visit, Komolov said. The miners were chosen for the trip by their strike committees. Bullock responded that Masalovich was traveling on the personal invitation of the U.S. ambassador and ``an organization cannot cancel an invitation to a private individual,'' he said. Bullock said embassy officials did not know if Masalovich had been removed from the strike committee, and that it was irrelevant, even if true. Bullock also denied the Foreign Ministry's claim that the embassy had been notified. ``We find the Foreign Ministry statement to be false and incomprehensible,'' he said. Hundreds of thousands of coal miners went on strike in July in the Soviet Union's first nationwide work stoppage in decades. The government quickly gave in, saying complaints of poor social and economic conditions were justified. But the struggling Soviet economy has been hard-pressed to fulfill those promises of more soap, food and social programs. Miners in Vorkuta _ famed in the Soviet Union as the site of harsh prison camps under former leader Josef Stalin _ struck again in October for five weeks, saying the government failed to keep its promises to increase pensions and wages and to improve living conditions. The miners are scheduled to meet with U.S. labor leaders, including AFL-CIO head Lane Kirkland.
